Award.AwardTitle: Mobile Summer Institutes: Creating Points of Transformation in Post-Secondary STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Academies Summer Institutes (SI) began in response to the 2003 National Resource Council report BIO2010: Transforming Undergraduate Education for Future Research Biologists and, with support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, have evolved from one site in 2003 to six sites in 2015, each conducting five day workshops to engage university faculty in adapting effective teaching approaches as revealed by recent educational research. The Mobile Summer Institutes (MSIs) are an innovative variation on the SI. They respond to the call for the need for all students to experience science courses that reflect current advances in science and teaching approaches and technologies that science education researchers have proven to be effective, as stated in the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (2014) and Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education, a 2011 document representing the views of over 500 biology faculty and administrators. The MSIs use Henderson's model of Four Categories of Change Strategies and add three new components to the current SI pedagogical training format: 1) peer evaluation to foster acquisition of reflective practices by participants; 2) a strategic planning workshop to leverage the newly acquired STEM reform vision and expertise supplied by the mobile institutes; and 3) a workshop for local administrators to foster awareness, buy-in and support for STEM reform initiatives by participants.

The MSIs will travel to college campuses to train participants in active learning methods and strategies for peer-evaluation that will allow them to provide feedback to one another so that they may continually improve their implementation of the active learning strategies in their classrooms. Participants will take part in workshops that will facilitate the development of plans to address specific institutional barriers that may inhibit educational reform on their own campuses. Workshops will also be held for local administrators to foster administrative support for the education reform initiatives that participants undertake. Finally, participants who have some prior experience in reforming their own classrooms will be trained to present the summer institute workshops so that, after being involved in two (MSIs) on their campuses, they can direct summer institutes on their campuses, thus increasing the impact of the MSIs beyond the project period. The host institutions will thus become nodes for diffusion of a common framework for educational reform within their growing local network of schools in addition to connecting with the greater SI community. The current project is essentially a proof of concept.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to improve college STEM education by increasing use of active, inclusive, student-centered teaching strategies. To achieve this goal, we developed a place-based version of a successful pedagogy training program, the National Academies Summer Institutes (SI), called the Mobile Summer Institutes on Scientific Teaching (MoSI). The MoSI focuses on both individual and institutional transformation by combining pedagogical training for current and future faculty with strategic planning to address institutional barriers to transforming teaching approaches and curricula. The MoSI also differs from the original SI in that it travels to host institutions to:

  1. produce a critical mass of faculty that share a conceptual framework, skill set and vision for classroom and curricular reform;
  2. create local teaching support and evaluation systems using a distributed model of peer-review and peer-mentoring to foster reflective teaching practices;
  3. facilitate local strategic planning to leverage the new knowledge and expertise in the department toward curricular reform;
  4. promote administrative support of local reform efforts through development and implementation of a scientific teaching workshop for administrators; and
  5. create local capacity for formal pedagogical training for current and future faculty.

As a result of this grant, we developed the MoSI, developed a cohort of over twenty MoSI trainers located across the nation to aid in running the MoSIs, offered 72 MoSIs at 38 institutions training nearly 1800 current and future faculty in active, inclusive teaching strategies. If we make the conservative estimate that each participant that successfully completed a MoSI taught approximately 100 students per semester, then we have had an impact on over a third of a million students.

Many of our host institutions have transitioned into a sustainable phase in which they are continuing to offer their own local MoSIs to expand the impact on their campus and local campuses. We have also made the transition to a self-funded model, where institutions pay to host MoSIs at their campuses. To date, thirteen institutions have funded MoSIs on their campuses with five of those being international campuses in Canada, China, England, Norway, Saudi Arabia. During the final year of the grant, in response to the pandemic, we developed an online version of the MoSI that was offered at three institutions, including our first medical school. This version not only allowed our professional development to continue during the pandemic but it provided much needed training in how to actively engage students in remote teaching venues. The online version of the MoSI will allow this type of professional development to continue during the pandemic and in the face of pandemic-related budget shortages cuts following the pandemic. In addition, the online version of the MoSI is much more cost-effective since there are no travel-related costs for the training team which means future access to hosting a MoSI will be much more equitable, particularly for under-resourced institutions.

Since active learning has been shown to increase student success and persistence and reduce achievement gaps for populations traditionally underserved by STEM disciplines, our project should increase retention and success of underrepresented students helping make our graduating populations look more like the populations from which they derive. Eventually, this will make our national STEM workforce more diverse which should help reduce the structural inequities embedded in our society, particularly in the health-related fields, where inequities have been highlighted by the current pandemic. Students who have a firm foundation in the process of science but end up in non-STEM careers should increase scientific literacy in the general population.
